ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Linear Systems. Linear Transformations. Too much computation. Some applications but honestly not enough for a class that advertises itself as a "with applications" title.
I learned how to do math with matrixes! Very fun.
I learned how to solve linear equations using matrices using various decompositions and methods.
linear algebra (matrix elimination, linear transformations, least squares solution, LU decomposition, determinants, singular value decomposition, projections, etc.)
Fundamental linear algebra knowledge
Learned about vector spaces, bases, and determinants.
linear skills

I learned about Linear Algebra and the various applications it has in practice. Specifically, I learned the ways in which matrices can be used a means to solve large-scale mathematical problems with numerous variables and moving pieces.
I learned about the fundamental theorem of linear algebra and basic proof logic.
matrix manipulation
I developed my skills in Linear Algebra, which was a quite difficult area for me.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The main strength of the course for me was the professor; he made content accessible and made sure we understood everything before moving on.
Exams are too hard. Psets were too easy. Please make this more about the students instead of making it a trauma bonding experience for general STEM majors.
I wish that there were more opportunities to practiceI really liked the little video quizzes we had in math 120, and I feel like adding those to 222 would help!

The class is taught thoroughly at the beginning, but it felt like we rushed towards the finish which was especially harmful because the topics at the end were more difficult. The exams also did not mimic the problem sets or the material we learned very closely at all.

strength: Abinand was a strong teacher

weaknesses: did not record lectures & had a patronizing attitude
Lectures move pretty fast

I wish it was better organized and there were more resources to help students. For example, I'd love if my section had access to recorded lectures given that other ones did. And it would be really nice if instructors hosted review session instead of having a poor TF have to deal with all sorts of questions about a bit inconsistently defined terminology.

The teaching was not effective. We didn't really cover any examples in class so that made it harder to do the homework assignments. A lot of the tutoring hours were cancelled with no notice. Professor Gopal tried to be helpful at office hours but it was difficult to get clear answers to questions.
Its fine overall, but a bit dry in general. The applications portion of this course was very brief and not very in depth.

Strength: Linear is important

Weakness: Instructors could not have been less helpful. God bless the peer tutors.

One way this course could be improved is providing optional supplementary videos and/or recording lectures. I am not the strongest math student by any means, so if I missed a lecture or even just missed a sentence while attending the lecture, this sometimes led to confusion after class. Without anywhere else to turn, I was essentially required to attend office hours for aid, which isn't the worst. However, a varied source of explanations and methods of teaching would have been greatly beneficial to me, especially considering that I often used other sources when studying and sometimes found them more useful than lectures/office hours. I am not saying that it is impossible to find resources on our own, but it would be great to have some listed in the syllabus or course, so we know which sources the professors themselves believe are good resources.
The release of assignments wasn't always timely and files on canvas were unorganized for some time.

I think the few times we looked at applications of the course material were very helpful in cementing my understanding of the class. I also appreciated the occasional recap of the class, its goals, and the logic we applied as we went through the semester so that I could stay on track. I wish my section was recorded, as it would have been helpful to hear responses to questions in class (that came up again while I reviewed) reiterated.

strengths: problem sets did not ask more than what was reasonable from students, grading structure was good

weaknesses: lecture was not very engaging, not much visual description or as the course title implies "application"

It basically covers every fundamental aspect of Linear Algebra and by taking this course I gained a comprehensive understanding of this subject. However, the intensity of the course is a little bit high, especially near the end of the term, when the materials became increasingly harder. If the course could be designed in a way that makes the progression of difficulty more gradual, that would be great.

The course was generally disorganized: it wasn't clear when psets were out, practice problem solutions were occasionally not thorough enough for someone to follow along and catch their mistakes, and half of the peer tutors hours were cancelled weekly. A lot of these issues could be improved by adding more work to solutions and keeping up to date with organization.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would, it is a solid introduction to linear algebra that covers many core concepts.
No. But if its for a requirement, just bite the bullet. I probably would have enjoyed 225 more though.

I think that I might have some hesitations because sometimes the class was a bit disorganized, and the feedback given was a little bit roughI know I had a teacher who told me when I didnt get a problem to just think about it more and told that to me in front of the entire class during a lecture, which was a bit disconcerting. (I asked an question, and that was the response).
I would recommend it as a required course but not a very smooth introduction if you havent taken linear algebra before.

if you need it for your major, take with Abinand Gopal (our class typically had higher means than other sections, likely due to thorough teaching of subject) tho definitely watch MIT lectures as a supplement. not a class to take for fun tho.
Yes if you want to get better at linear algebra
Maybe? The class is just kind of painful. I am really not a proofs guy so I didn't take 225 but now I am thinking I probably should have.
Only if required. The teaching isn't good and the course is frustrating. In terms of workload it's okay.
I would definitely recommend this class to anyone, irregardless of major. Linear algebra is so fundamental to our society and such an interesting math.
Would not recommend unless you need it.
If you are a major in any QR field, then yes. Otherwise, I don't see much need to take it.

it was helpful to get an intro into linear algebra without proofs, but lecture was not taught in a very comprehensible way (you'll learn how to manipulate matrices but you won't even be able to explain what a matrix is)
I would, since this is one of the fundamental courses for anyone studying Mathematics, but I would remind them that it would be quite demanding.
